fields.descriptive_line: Enamelled brass ('London Enamel' formerly 'Surrey Enamel'), probably made by Anthony Hatch and Stephen Pilcherd, London, 1650-1680
fields.physical_description: Brass candlestick, cast, with blue, green and white matt enamel, the fields for the enamels cast in the mould, decorated with flowers, the foot circular with flowers and foliage, the stem in the form of a double baluster (once separated by a wide flat drip pan), both parts cast in the same mould (the lower part cut down), the socket a rigid tapering cylinder. The drip pan was presumably lost when the candlesticks were converted to oil.
fields.public_access_description:
These candlesticks are from a distinct group of 17th-century cast and enamelled brasswares that include stirrups, mirror-frames, fire-dogs, sconces, badges and sword-hilts. The colours used for the enamelling were limited to matt black, white, blue, green, yellow and red and the cast work is usually roughly finished. Some have Royalist associations including badges decorated with the Royal arms.

The items in the group are distinguished by their method of production: the fields to be enamelled were cast in the original moulds and not, as was more common, engraved (champlévé) or enclosed (cloisonné). They were for a long time referred to as Surrey Enamels after the author Charles R. Beard ascribed their manufacture to a factory in Esher, Surrey, but documentary evidence makes a strong case for their reattribution to the London workshops of Anthony Hatch and Stephen Pilcherd.

Hatch, a prominent member of the Armourers and Braziers Company, supplied an enamelled brass chimney piece to the Company, which was placed in the Court Room. This was presumably similar in style to the other enamelled wares from this group, which of course included other wares associated with fireplaces. Hatch worked with Pilchard, another member of the Armourers and Braziers Company. 

The comparatively small output of work and the repeated use of identical moulds for the stems of candlesticks, firedogs and cups suggests these objects are the products one workshop. Even domestic wares decorated with enamel would have been expensive, which implies that the workshop that produced them would have had a small but comparatively wealthy clientele.
fields.bibliography:
Blair, Claude, "Surrey Enamels Reattributed: Part 1", <u>Journal of the Antique Metalware Society</u>, Volume 13, June 2005, pp. 2-9
See p. 5, Fig. 7: Painting of the Paston Family heirlooms, before 1679, illustrated showing strombus shell cup whose stem was cast in the same mould (ref. Historical Significance)
Blair, Claude, and Patterson, Angus, "Surrey Enamels Reattributed: Part 2, An Illustrated List of Known Types", <u>The Journal of the Antique Metalware Society</u>, June 2006, vol. 14, pp. 10-21 (see esp. p. 20)
Includes full bibliography.
On p. 20 is an exposition of comparative objects cast in the same moulds (ref. Historical Significance)
fields.history_note: Probably made in the London workshop of Anthony Hatch (active from 1632, died, probably in London, 1689) or Stephen Pilchard. Historical significance: The items in the group are distinguished by their method of production: the fields to be enamelled were cast in the original moulds and not, as was more common, engraved (champlévé) or enclosed (cloisonné). They were for a long time referred to as Surrey Enamels after the author Charles R. Beard ascribed their manufacture to a factory in Esher, Surrey, but documentary evidence makes a storng case for their reattribution to the London workshops of Anthony Hatch and Stephen Pilcherd. Hatch, a prominent member of the Armourers and Braziers Company, supplied an enamelled brass chimney piece to the Company, which was placed in the Court Room. This was presumably similar in style to the other enamelled wares from this group, which of course included other wares associated with fireplaces. Hatch worked with Pilchard, another member of the Armourers and Braziers Company. Few examples of these enamelled wares survive and along with the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the V&A has the largest holding in the world at around a dozen examples. The comparatively small output of work and the repeated use of identical moulds for the stems of candlesticks, firedogs and cups suggests these objects are the products one workshop. These are significant candlesticks as they add considerable weight to this idea. The V&A also holds a pair of stems (7668 & 7669-1861) with cast in the same moulds as the baluster stems on these candlesticks. The Metropolitan Museum in New York also owns a pair of firedogs (64.101.1615 & 1616) and Norwich Castle Museum & Art Gallery owns an unusual mounted strombus shell cup (1938.149.2: shown also in the painting of before 1679 of the Paston Family heirlooms in the same museum) with stems also cast in the same moulds as these candlesticks. Even domestic wares decorated with enamel would have been expensive, which implies that the workshop that produced them would have had a small but comparatively wealthy clientele.
fields.historical_context_note: This candlestick is from a group of cast and enamelled brasswares that include stirrups, mirror-frames, fire-dogs, sconces, badges and sword-hilts. The colours used for the enamelling were limited to matt black, white, blue, green, yellow and red and the cast work is usually roughly finished. Some have Royalist associations including badges decorated with the Royal arms.
